fields.title: Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum
fields.description:
__Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum__

The __Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum__ (Khmer: សារមន្ទីរឧក្រិដ្ឋកម្មប្រល័យពូជសាសន៍ទួលស្លែង), commonly known as __Tuol Sleng__, which translates to _"Hill of the Poisonous Trees"_ or _"Strychnine Hill,"_ is located in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. It serves as a stark and solemn reminder of the brutal atrocities committed during the Cambodian genocide under the Khmer Rouge regime.

### Historical Background

Originally established as a secondary school, the building was seized and repurposed by the Khmer Rouge in 1975 to become __Security Prison 21 (S-21)__, one of the most notorious centers of imprisonment, interrogation, torture, and execution during the regime’s rule from 1975 to 1979.

### The Prison and Its Victims

- Between 1976 and 1979, approximately __20,000__ men, women, and children were detained at Tuol Sleng.
- Tuol Sleng was one of between 150 and 196 similar detention and execution centers operated by the Khmer Rouge secret police, known as the __Santebal__ (literally meaning _“keeper of peace”_).
- Prisoners were often accused of opposing the regime or suspected of espionage, frequently on flimsy or fabricated evidence.
- Detainees were subjected to brutal interrogations, forced confessions under torture, and many were later executed or sent to killing fields.

### Aftermath and Justice

In __July 2010__, the __Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia (ECCC)__ convicted __Kang Kek Iew__, the prison’s chief, also known by his alias _Duch_, for crimes against humanity and grave breaches of the 1949 Geneva Conventions. Duch was sentenced to life imprisonment and died in 2020 while serving his sentence.

![Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum](//images.ctfassets.net/ntvh3j97dkce/5mkVNumcqgei5e40nFhbdS/e9b4e35309105c11e56266a8a03ea334/IMG_0129-min.webp)

### The Museum Today

The __Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum__ now functions as a memorial and educational site:

- It preserves the prison’s original buildings, cells, and equipment used for torture.
- Photographs and records of victims are displayed to honor their memory.
- It educates visitors from around the world about the horrors of the Khmer Rouge era.
- The museum plays a vital role in promoting awareness about human rights and the importance of preventing genocide.

Visiting Tuol Sleng is a deeply moving experience that underscores the resilience of survivors and the importance of historical memory in healing a nation scarred by genocide.

---

*Remembering the past is essential to ensuring a more just and humane future.*
